channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Coronavirus News Updates
item.description: Investigators have uncovered a fraud ring that may have siphoned millions of dollars in unemployment payments. With more than two-thirds of states significantly relaxing restrictions, an uptick in cases is predicted.
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Barack Obama in 2018. “I’ve always loved joining commencements,” he posted on Twitter this month.

item.title: Suspect in Arbery Shooting Offered to Help Deal With Potential Trespasser
item.description: Two months before Ahmaud Arbery was killed, one of the suspects told the police he could be notified if a nearby homeowner noticed any suspicious activity.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset
item.media:credit: Dylan Wilson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The construction site in Satilla Shores where video cameras had captured someone entering multiple times over several months.

item.title: Feds Suspect Vast Fraud Network Is Targeting U.S. Unemployment Systems
item.description: Investigators see evidence of a sophisticated international attack they said could siphon hundreds of millions of dollars that were intended for the unemployed.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:description: The attack has exploited state unemployment systems at a time when they are straining to process a crush of claims.

item.title: Obama Says U.S. Lacks Leadership on Virus in Commencement Speech
item.description: The virus has “torn back the curtain on the idea that the folks in charge know what they’re doing,” the former president said. “A lot of them aren’t even pretending to be in charge.”
item.dc:creator: Audra D. S. Burch and John Eligon

item.title: Donald Trump Jr. Smears Biden With Baseless Instagram Post
item.description: Signaling the increasingly dark tactics of the Trump campaign, the president’s oldest son falsely accused Mr. Biden of preying on children.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin
item.media:description: Donald Trump Jr. often goes even further than his father’s accusations and insinuations.

item.title: Cody Latimer of the Redskins Faces Assault and Weapons Charges
item.description: Deputies went to an apartment complex in Colorado early Saturday morning after receiving a report of gunfire inside a unit, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor

item.title: Fred Willard, Comic Actor Who Thrived in Ensembles, Dies at 86
item.description: Mr. Willard, who was nominated for Emmys for his roles on “Modern Family” and “Everybody Loves Raymond,” was a frequent and memorable collaborator with the director Christopher Guest.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: Fred Willard in Los Angeles in 2011.

item.title: Top Democrats Open Investigation Into Ouster of State Dept. Inspector General
item.description: The lawmakers said that they believed Secretary of State Mike Pompeo recommended Steve Linick’s removal because he had opened an investigation into Mr. Pompeo’s conduct.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: Steve Linick, who President Trump removed from his post as inspector general for the State Department, after a closed briefing on Capitol Hill in Washington last year.

item.title: Exotic Lizards Creep Into Georgia. Don’t Expect Southern Hospitality.
item.description: State wildlife officials have warned residents to be on the lookout for the Argentine black and white tegu, an invasive lizard species that is threatening native creatures.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz

item.title: Justin Amash Abandons Third-Party Presidential Bid
item.description: The Michigan conservative said the “extraordinary challenges” of campaigning in the current environment had discouraged him from challenging President Trump and Joe Biden.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Burns
item.media:description: “I continue to believe that a candidate from outside the old parties, offering a vision of government grounded in liberty and equality, can break through in the right environment,” Mr. Amash said. “But this environment presents extraordinary challenges.”

item.title: At the Drive-In: Thrills, Chills, Popcorn and Hand Sanitizer
item.description: Cabin fever and movies drew carloads of people to the drive-in theater in Warwick, N.Y., on Friday as it opened for business again.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.media:credit: Daniel Dorsa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cars at the Warwick Drive-In practiced social distancing as their occupants awaited the first movies of the theater’s season.

item.title: Sorry, Abe Lincoln Is Not on the Ballot
item.description: But the 16th president is showing up quite a bit in the 2020 race. He remains uncommitted.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall and Matt Flegenheimer
item.media:description: President Trump participating in a Fox News virtual town hall at the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, D.C.

item.title: ‘I Can’t Turn My Brain Off’: PTSD and Burnout Threaten Medical Workers
item.description: Before Covid-19, health care workers were already vulnerable to depression and suicide. Mental health experts now fear even more will be prone to trauma-related disorders.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman
item.media:description: Bridget Ryan, a peer supporter and assistant nurse manager at Christiana Hospital in Newark, Del., hugged Christina Burke, a nurse, after a recent counseling session.

item.title: 5 Takeaways on U.S. Involvement in the World’s Worst Humanitarian Crisis
item.description: Thousands of civilians have died in Yemen, and American-made bombs sold to the Saudis have played a key role as the White House has sought to boost the arms industry.
item.dc:creator: Michael LaForgia and Walt Bogdanich
item.media:description: President Trump discussing weapon sales with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia in March 2018.

item.title: Raytheon Finds Ally in Trump Aide: Selling the Bombs Killing Civilians in Yemen
item.description: President Trump sees arms deals as jobs generators for firms like Raytheon, which has made billions in sales to the Saudi coalition. The Obama administration initially backed the Saudis too, but later regretted it as thousands died.
item.dc:creator: Michael LaForgia and Walt Bogdanich
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Stacey Abrams Wants More Than the Vice Presidency
item.description: She wants the Democrats to reach a different kind of swing voter — those who otherwise stay home. And she says she can help Joe Biden do it.
item.dc:creator: Elaina Plott
item.media:credit: Johnathon Kelso for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stacey Abrams, who has made no secret of her desire to be Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s running mate, says Democrats must do more to persuade Americans of color to vote.

item.title: Judge Orders Los Angeles to Move Homeless People Away From Freeways
item.description: The order, which takes effect next Friday, will apply to about 6,500 people living under freeways and on their ramps.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:description: A federal judge ordered Los Angeles to find housing for homeless people living near freeways, citing health risks from pollution and passing cars.

item.title: Trump Removes State Dept. Inspector General
item.description: A top Democrat in Congress described the move as “an outrageous act,” and said that the inspector general, Steve Linick, had opened an investigation into Secretary of State Mike Pompeo.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Maggie Haberman
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
item.media:description: Steve A. Linick was removed as State Department inspector general on Friday night. President Trump said he no longer had “fullest confidence” in him.

item.title: Coronavirus World Live Coverage: Saudi Arabia, Ukraine, China, Netherlands
item.description: A least 100 babies born into Ukraine’s booming surrogate motherhood business have become marooned in the country, and more are coming. Brazil’s contradictory response has made it an emerging center of the pandemic.

item.title: U.S. Is Said to Plan to File Antitrust Charges Against Google
item.description: The case may be joined by state attorneys general in what would be one of the biggest antitrust actions by the United States since the late 1990s.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang, David McCabe and Daisuke Wakabayashi
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Regulators are focusing on Google’s dominance in the online advertising industry and in online search.

item.title: A Sitting President, Riling the Nation During a Crisis
item.description: By smearing his opponents, championing conspiracy theories and pursuing vendettas, President Tru​mp has reverted to his darkest political tactics in spite of a pandemic hurting millions of Americans.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Burns, Maggie Haberman, Jonathan Martin and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has created conflict with new intensity in recent days, rattling some supportive Republicans.

item.title: House Passes $3 Trillion Aid Bill Over Republican Opposition
item.description: The bill faces a veto threat from President Trump, near-unanimous opposition by Republicans and complaints from Democrats, but leaders called it their opening offer in talks on the next round of pandemic relief.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: Representatives Kendra Horn of Oklahoma, left, and Elaine Luria of Virginia, both Democrats, in the Capitol after a vote on Friday.

item.title: 'Credible Threats' to Kill Gov. Gretchen Whitmer Lead to Charges, Police Say
item.description: Robert S. Tesh made “credible threats” via social media messages to kill Gov. Gretchen Whitmer and Michigan’s attorney general, Dana Nessel, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Mele
item.media:credit: Pool, Michigan Governors Office, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan has been the target of protests over her stay-at-home orders during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Kobe Bryant Autopsy Report Is Released After Helicopter Crash
item.description: The pilot of the helicopter that crashed in January, killing Mr. Bryant and eight others, didn’t have alcohol or drugs in his system. The victims all died from blunt trauma.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:credit: National Transportation Safety Board, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Investigators at the scene of the helicopter crash that killed the basketball star Kobe Bryant, his daughter Gianna and seven others in January.

item.title: Intelligence Chief Reduces Size of Counterterrorism Office
item.description: The cuts to the National Counterterrorism Center were smaller than some former officials feared. The changes will allow intelligence agencies to shift personnel to other threats.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.category: Office of the Director of National Intelligence
item.media:description: Richard Grenell, the acting director of national intelligence.
